abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Fifth Education
            (Vocational) Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. Most of
            the objectives were achieved, its impact has been
            significant, sustainability is likely, and both the Borrower
            and the Bank acted satisfactorily. Several major lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, government project
            implementing units need to be free of protracted
            bureaucratic procedures so project funds can utilized in a
            timely fashion. Second, monitoring and evaluation units need
            to be established at the commencement of a project so
            feedback can be obtained during the implementation period.
            Third, support items, particularly trained instructors, need
            to be produced at an early stage of the project
            implementation cycle. Fourth, it is essential to establish
            industrial employer commitment to the scheme before
            implementation. Fifth, the civil works component was
            seriously delayed in this project due to delays in site
            acquisition, poor initial designs, poor supervision, and
            delays in construction. The lessons learned from this
            experience are to: 1) define more clearly the specific
            responsibilities of involved parties; 2) ensure the supply
            of sufficient and suitably qualified staff for supervision;
            3) supervise more closely construction work; and 4) ensure
            closer collaboration between national and provincial
            governments. Lastly, contracting equipment procurement
            agencies greatly increase the efficiency of equipment procurement.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Vocational Training Project's
            objectives are: (a) to help increase the Government's
            capability to plan, manage and evaluate skill training; (b)
            accelerate the output and improve the quality of skill
            training institutions; and (c) improve the productivity of
            employed workers. It will consist of: (a) construction,
            furniture and equipment for the National Training
            Development Institute, and for 6 new training centers; (b)
            rehabilitating and re-equipping of 31 existing centers; (c)
            furniture and equipment for the Secretariats of the National
            Training Board and the Provincial Training Boards; (d)
            incremental staff salaries and preparation of future
            projects; (e) staff training; and (f) technical assistance,
            to be financed by the UNDP.
